### BASIC TRIGONOMETRIC INTEGRALS

$$
\begin{array}{c|c@{}c}
    f(x) & & F(x) \\
    \hline
    \cos x && \sin x + c \\

    \sec x \cdot \sec x && \tan x + c \\
    \tan x \cdot \sec x && \sec^2 x + c \\
    \csc x \cdot \csc x \\
    \cot x \cdot \csc x \\
    e^x  \\
    \ln x & &\dfrac{1}{x} \\
\end{array}
$$

There are other trigonometric functions whose integrals are not so
obvious.

$$\int\tan(x)dx=$$

$$\begin{align*}
\int \tan x \, dx 
&= \int \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} \, dx \\[6pt]
&= \int \frac{1}{\cos x} \sin x \, dx \\[6pt]
\text{Let } t = \cos x \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; &dt = -\sin x \, dx \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; \sin x \, dx = -dt \\[6pt]
&= \int \frac{1}{t} (-dt) \\[6pt]
&= - \int \frac{1}{t} \, dt \\[6pt]
&= -\ln |t| + C \\[6pt]
&= -\ln |\cos x| + C \\[6pt]
&= \ln \left|\frac{1}{\cos x}\right| + C \\[6pt]
&= \ln |\sec x| + C.
\end{align*}$$

OTHER TRIGONOMETRIC INTEGRALS

$$\begin{aligned}\int\tan(x)\:dx&=\\&=\end{aligned}$$

$$\begin{aligned}\int\cot(x)\:dx&=\\&=\end{aligned}$$

$$\int\csc(x)\:dx=\ln\left|\csc(x)-\cot(x)\right|+C$$

$$\int\sec(x)\:dx=\ln\left|\sec(x)+\tan(x)\right|+C$$

Note that $\int\tan(x)dx$ and $\int cot(x)dx$ havetwo forms. Choose the
one that works best for you!

For integrands we do not recognize as derivatives, some simplification,
identities, or applying the substitution method will help.

### Basic Identities:You must know these

$${\frac{1}{\cos(x)}}\quad\sec(x)={\frac{1}{\cos(x)}}\quad{\frac{\sin(x)}{\cos(x)}}=\quad={\frac{1}{\cos(x)}}$$

$$\csc(x)=\frac{1}{1}$$

Try rewriting with identities:
$$\int\frac{\cos(\theta)}{\sin^2(\theta)}d\theta $$

Try U-Substitution:

$$\begin{align*}
  \int\frac{\cos(\theta)}{\sin^2(\theta)}d\theta \\
  u = \sin\theta \implies du = \cos\theta dx \\
  \implies \int \frac{du}{u^2} \\
  = \int u^{-2} du \\
  = \frac{u^{-1}}{-1} + c \\
  = -\frac{1}{u} + c \\
  = -\frac{1}{\sin\theta} + c \\
  = -\csc\theta + c \\
\end{align*}$$

E5 Use u substitution to find the particular solution of
$g(x)=\int\cos^{2}(x)\sin(x)dx$ ,given that $g(\pi)=\frac{4}{3}$

$$
\begin{align*}
  u = \cos x &\implies du = - \sin x dx \\
  \implies G(x) &= - \int u^2 du \\
  G(x) &= - \frac{u^3}{3} + c \\
  G(x) &= - \frac{\cos^3 x}{3} + c \\
  \frac{4}{3} &= - \frac{\cos^3 \pi}{3} + c \\
  c &= \frac{4}{3} + \frac{\cos^3 \pi}{3} \\
  c &= 1 \\
  G(x) &= - \frac{\cos^3 x}{3} + 1 \\
\end{align*}
$$
